1.text: Like snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honor is not fitting for a fool.

2.text: Like a fluttering sparrow, like a darting swallow, so the undeserved curse doesn’t come to rest.

3.text: A whip is for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the back of fools!

4.text: Don’t answer a fool according to his folly, lest you also be like him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own eyes.

6.text: One who sends a message by the hand of a fool is cutting off feet and drinking violence.

7.text: Like the legs of the lame that hang loose: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

8.text: As one who binds a stone in a sling, so is he who gives honor to a fool.

9.text: Like a thornbush that goes into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

10.text: As an archer who wounds all, so is he who hires a fool or he who hires those who pass by.

11.text: As a dog that returns to his vomit, so is a fool who repeats his folly.

12.text: Do you see a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.text: The sluggard says, “There is a lion in the road! A fierce lion roams the streets!”

14.text: As the door turns on its hinges, so does the sluggard on his bed.

15.text: The sluggard buries his hand in the dish. He is too lazy to bring it back to his mouth.

16.text: The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who answer with discretion.

17.text: Like one who grabs a dog’s ears is one who passes by and meddles in a quarrel not his own.

18.text: Like a madman who shoots torches, arrows, and death,

19.text: is the man who deceives his neighbor and says, “Am I not joking?”

20.text: For lack of wood a fire goes out. Without gossip, a quarrel dies down.

21.text: As coals are to hot embers, and wood to fire, so is a contentious man to kindling strife.

22.text: The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels, they go down into the innermost parts.

23.text: Like silver dross on an earthen vessel are the lips of a fervent one with an evil heart.

24.text: A malicious man disguises himself with his lips, but he harbors evil in his heart.

25.text: When his speech is charming, don’t believe him; for there are seven abominations in his heart.

26.text: His malice may be concealed by deception, but his wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.

27.text: Whoever digs a pit shall fall into it. Whoever rolls a stone, it will come back on him.

28.text: A lying tongue hates those it hurts; and a flattering mouth works ruin.
